title: U.K. Government Outlines ‘Worst-Case Scenario’ for No-Deal Brexit
text:
LONDON—The British government described potential shortages of fuel and medicines, long traffic jams at ports and rising food prices in a report outlining its “reasonable worst-case scenario” if the U.K. left the European Union without a deal to smooth its exit.

The report, which the government was compelled to publish on Wednesday after opposition lawmakers voted for its release in Parliament, paints a bleak picture of fuel shortages in London and worries over access to medicines caught up in a traffic snarl at ports in France as customs and other checks are implemented for the first time in more than four decades.

“Protests and counter protests will take place across the U.K. and may absorb significant police resource,” the document said.

Michael Gove, left, the government minister who oversees planning for a no-deal Brexit, on Wednesday wrote to opposition lawmakers to say the government document wasn’t a prediction of what will happen if the U.K. leaves the European Union without a deal. Photo: jessica taylor/u.k. parliament/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

In a letter to opposition lawmakers, Michael Gove, the government minister who oversees the no-deal planning, said the document wasn’t a prediction of what would happen but rather provided a “deliberately stretching context for government planning to ensure that we are prepared.”

Prime Minister Boris Johnson has vowed to deliver on the 2016 referendum result and said he would take the U.K. out of the EU, if necessary without a deal to secure a graduated transition out of the bloc. The U.K. is due to leave the EU on Oct. 31, but that date now looks uncertain after a majority of lawmakers voted to pass a law forcing the government to request a delay if a deal isn’t struck with the EU.

Much of the predicted chaos stems from a huge traffic jam at ports on either side of the English Channel that would build up from day one, when the flow of trucks would drop by as much as 60%.

The document said significant disruption at ports in Dover, in the U.K., and Calais, France, could last up to six months. Trucks could face delays of up to 2½ days as they line up for customs checks before boarding boats to cross the Channel. That could affect the flow of medicines into the country and spark panic buying of fuel. It could also push up the price of certain foods, the report said. Three-quarters of British medicines are imported through the narrow strait.

Businesses and households also would face higher electricity prices, the report said.

Related Video In the last two weeks, U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has suspended Parliament, unsuccessfully called for elections, and lost his majority. WSJ’s Max Colchester explains what the recent political drama means for Brexit. Photo: Jessica Taylor/U.K. Parliament/AFP

The government has previously said it is taking steps to mitigate some of the worst effects of a sudden break with the country’s largest trading partners. The scenario the government describes is only if the government doesn’t strike deals with individual EU countries to mitigate the effects of leaving the bloc and that the relationship with the EU is “as a whole unsympathetic.”

The report by the government’s cabinet office warned that the impact of disruption would hit Britain’s poorest hardest. It warned that “low income groups will be disproportionately affected by any price rises in food and fuel.”

The government has repeatedly delayed the publication of the report on the no-deal preparations known by the code name “Project Yellow Hammer.”

Businesses and economists have long warned of the threat to the British economy of suddenly breaking with the EU. Many businesses have stockpiled goods to prepare for any disruption to decades-old trade links with the rest of Europe.

Mr. Johnson has repeatedly said the U.K. must be able to threaten leaving without a deal to get improved divorce terms from the EU. He has tried to call an election to resolve the Brexit impasse, but his minority government doesn’t have the votes to force a poll.

Britain has already spent years preparing for a no-deal exit. The Bank of England recently softened its estimates over the effect of no-deal, saying it would shrink the economy by 5.5%, adding that preparation by the government has mitigated some of the worst effects.

Under the government’s worst-case scenario, the country would overnight sever ties with the trade bloc, which would impose tariffs, animal-safety checks and other controls at borders for the first time in more than four decades.

A major worry is that businesses and individuals aren’t taking steps to prepare for a no-deal Brexit. The report estimated that between 50% and 85% of exporters using the Channel wouldn’t be ready for customs checks on day one.

Brexit has already been delayed twice and some businesses have expressed apathy at having to prepare yet again. The government has launched a large-scale ad campaign to raise awareness of the steps British people and companies need to take.

Fears of a no-deal Brexit, along with sluggish economic data, have weakened the pound, which has been trading around two-year lows against the dollar.

The government is looking to strike a deal with the EU at a summit in October, though there is skepticism that it has time to negotiate a revised deal and secure its passage through Parliament.

Write to Max Colchester at max.colchester@wsj.com and Stephen Fidler at stephen.fidler@wsj.com
